questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the requirements of good lighting?

choices.text: Colour of light should approximate daylight
Ceilings and roofs must have a 50% reflection factor

questions.solution:
For good lighting in a room, ceilings and roofs must have an 80% reflection factor.

The requirements of good lighting are:

  • Sufficient light to prevent eye strain. An illumination of 15 to 20-foot candles is accepted for satisfactory vision.
  • Distribution of light must be uniform with the same intensity over the whole field of work
  • Absence of glare
  • Absence of sharp shadows
  • The source of light should be constant and steady
  • The colour of light should approximate the colour of daylight
  • Ceilings and roofs must have an 80% reflection factor. Walls must have 50 to 60%, furniture 30 to 40% and floors 15 to 20%.

questions.text: What is the basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision?
questions.solution: The basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision is accepted to be 15 - 20 foot candles. The illumination requirements vary from as little as 5 foot candles in stairways and corridors to 100 foot candles in some industries.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about daylight factor?

choices.text: D.F. = Instantaneous illumination outdoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination indoors
D.F. = Instantaneous illumination indoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination outdoors
D.F. = Delayed illumination indoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination outdoors
D.F. = Delayed illumination outdoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination indoors

questions.solution:
Daylight factor (D.F.) is the ratio of the illumination at a given point to illumination at a point exposed simultaneously to the whole hemisphere of the sky (taken as 500-foot candles) excluding direct sunlight.

The D.F. is used for the measurement of daylight. It is determined by a modified photo-electric meter called daylight factor meter.

In living rooms, the daylight factor should be at least 8% and in kitchens, it should be 10%.

questions.text: You have been requested to inspect the working conditions of an office for clerks. What is the standard illumination recommended for such a space?
questions.solution:
The standard illumination recommended for general office work is 400 lux.

questions.text: What is the intensity of sound produced during whispering?
questions.solution:
Whispering produces a sound of 20 – 30 dB.

Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations. It is expressed in decibels (dB). The intensity of sounds produced during various activities is listed below.

Source Loudness
Whispering 20 – 30 dB
Normal conversation 60 – 65 dB
Heavy street traffic 60 – 80 dB
Boiler factories 120 dB

The frequency of sound is expressed in hertz (Hz). The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz.

questions.text: What is the upper limit of daily exposure to noise which people can tolerate without hearing damage?
questions.solution:
The upper limit of daily exposure to noise which people can tolerate without hearing damage is 85 dB. This is the maximum acceptable noise level.

It has been observed that the human ear responds in a non-uniform way to different sound-pressure levels. A weighting curve, called curve A has been constructed which takes into account the subjective effects of sound. Sound-pressure levels are therefore expressed in dBA because this reflects the perception of that sound emission by the normal human ear.

questions.text: A  steel plant worker presented with sudden onset of bilateral hearing loss after hearing a blast in the plant. On examination, both his tympanic membranes were ruptured. What would have been the minimum intensity of the blast to cause this injury?
questions.solution:
A minimum intensity of 160 dB can lead to rupture of the tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with complaints of whistling and buzzing in both his ears since yesterday. He gives a history of being exposed to continuous noise due to construction near his house. At what intensity of noise do such conditions begin to occur?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of auditory fatigue that begins to appear with exposure to noise at 90 dB.

questions.text: The WHO defines disabling hearing loss in adults as a hearing loss of more than:
questions.solution:
According to WHO, disabling hearing loss refers to hearing loss greater than 35 dB in the better hearing ear in adults.

WHO grades of hearing loss:

Grade of hearing loss range Range of hearing loss
0: No impairment < 20 dB
1: Mild 20 - 34 dB
2: Moderate 35 - 49 dB
3: Moderately Severe 50 - 64 dB
4: Severe 65 - 79 dB
5: Profound >80 dB

questions.text: Which of the following is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation?
questions.solution:
Rad is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation by tissue or material. It has been replaced by the SI unit which is gray (Gy).

questions.text: What is the SI unit of radiation dose equivalent?
questions.solution:
The SI unit of radiation dose equivalent is sievert (Sv).

Dose equivalent (H) = Absorbed dose (D) x Quality factor (Q)

The quality factor depends upon the density of ionization produced in the tissue by radiation. The factor Q for X-rays, γ-rays and electrons is 1 and that for an alpha particle is 20.

questions.text: What is the permissible dose of manmade radiation per year?
questions.solution: The permissible dose of manmade radiation is 5 rads per year.

questions.text: A young girl who is 1 month pregnant is concerned about a chest X-ray that she had taken 3 weeks back. What is the dose of radiation below which deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen?
questions.solution:
Deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen below 5 rads or 50 mSv of radiation.

Dose limits of radiation exposure are:

  • Occupational exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 20 mSv/year averaged over 5 consecutive years / 30 mSv in a year.
  • General public exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 1 mSv/year
  • Occupational exposure for pregnant staff - Effective dose to the fetus should not exceed 1mSv/year (same as the general public).

For pregnant patients who require diagnostics with exposure to ionising radiation, the radiation protection principles are followed:

  • The exposure should be justified
  • The dose should be as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA principle)
  • The dose limit is not particularly specified as it involves a single time exposure to diagnostic radiation. Usually, the effective dose to the fetus is <1msv and deterministic effects to the fetus are not seen below 50 mSv (5 Rad).

This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy and clarity on the topic of Radiation exposure protection as per the guidlines setup by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) which have been adopted by the Govt.of India Atomic Energy Regulatory Board.

questions.text: What was the 10 days rule in radiation related to?
questions.solution:
The 10 days rule in radiation was related to pregnancy. It is aimed at preventing unintentional exposure of the embryo or fetus to radiation.

This rule states that if a radiograph is being done on the abdomen or pelvis of a woman in her childbearing age, then it should be done during the 10 days following the onset of menstruation. 

In most situations, there is growing evidence that strict adherence to the "ten-day rule" may be unnecessarily restrictive. Since organogenesis starts 3 to 5 weeks post-conception, it was felt that radiation exposure in early pregnancy couldn't result in malformation. Based on this, it was suggested to do away with the 10-day rule and replace it with a 28-day rule. This means that radiological examination if justified, can be carried throughout the cycle until a period is missed.
